Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Fe-nanoparticle Coating of Anisotropic Magnet Powder for Nanocomposite Permanent Magnets with Enhanced (BH)max
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project proposes the development of an innovative and facile method to synthesize composite magnet powders coated with Fe and/or Fe-Co nanoparticles and to consolidate them into high performance anisotropic nanocomposite magnets. It was theoretically predicted in the 1990s that two phase exchange-coupled nanocomposite magnets consisting of a hard magnetic phase with high magnetocrystalline anisotropy and a soft magnetic phase with high saturation magnetization may exhibit a maximum energy product (BH)max twice the value of the current magnets. In this research effort, Fe and Fe-Co nanoparticles will be deposited onto hard magnetic powders by combined chemical and physical methods. Unlike previously employed techniques, the proposed approach allows the control of the size of soft magnetic phase to the nanoscale. Moreover, the approach is compatible with mass production. Subsequent consolidation of these composite powders by pressure and temperature assisted methods will lead to a new generation of high performance anisotropic nanocomposite permanent magnets with a (BH)max much higher than that of the current commercial magnets. The multiple choices for the core powder will result in new improved magnets for close-to-room-temperature applications (Nd2Fe14B-based), high temperature applications (SmCo5- and Sm2Fe17Nx-based) and ultra-high temperature applications (Sm2Co17-based).
The success in the development of the new (nano)composite magnets will directly result in the improvement of the functionality of electromagnetic devices and eventually lead to new applications not possible with the current permanent magnets. The higher performance magnets will result in even lighter weight, smaller footprint and lower the total system cost for electromagnetic devices in both commercial and military applications. The most well known applications are in: hybrid cars (permanent magnet motors and generators, sensors and actuators), spacecraft (momentum wheels, reaction wheels, stepper motors, ion propulsion), microwave sources (traveling wave tube amplifiers, klystrons, magnetrons), microwave components (isolators, circulators), inertial guidance (accelerometers, gyros), and other commercial systems (computer disk drives, computer printers, audio systems, satellite communication, medical imaging, stepper motors, etc). The proposal is a multidisciplinary enterprise involving physics, chemistry, and metallurgy. The bottom-up approach to the synthesis of nanocomposite magnets with uniform and controllable thickness of the soft magnetic shell formed from the precursor nanoparticle coating, will allow for an in-detail experimental characterization of magnetic interactions. This will provide valuable information to understand and substantially diminish the gap between the theoretical predictions and engineering capabilities.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fe-nanoparticle Coating of Anisotropic Magnet Powder for Nanocomposite Permanent Magnets with Enhanced (BH)max

 

Project Outcome: Stronger permanent magnets are important for increasing the energy efficiency of communication systems, hybrid/electric vehicles, wind turbines, fossil fuel free transportation systems, and new energy storage systems. The new class of permanent magnets, called nanocomposite magnets, should dramatically increase the performance of permanent magnet systems used in static and dynamic applications. The challenges for the fabrication of nanocomposite magnets include (i) the development of nanostructure without contamination, (ii) densification without grain growth. In this project we propose to address these difficulties through a ‘bottom-up’ approach to develop a technology for the fabrication of nanocomposite anisotropic precursors.

 We have synthesized, for the first time, samarium-cobalt permanent magnet nanoflakes with the magnetic performance similar to that of the bulk counterparts. We have also developed a method to uniformly deposit soft magnetic Fe and Fe-Co nanoparticles on the hard magnetic Sm-Co and Pr-Co core particles to form nanocomposite powder precursors. (Sm,Pr)Co5 and PrCo5 nanoflakes with different stoichiometries were synthesized as a hard magnetic precursor. The nanoflakes had a thickness in the range of 10-100 nm, which were fabricated by surfactant assisted high energy ball milling. Soft magnetic Fe and Fe-Co nanoparticles were chemically synthesized. The saturation magnetization, Ms, ranged from 18 kG to 20 kG for Fe nanoparticles and from 19 to 22 kG for Fe-Co nanoparticles. Anisotropic Sm-Co/Fe and Sm-Co/Fe-Co composite powders were formed by high energy blending from precursor micron-size powders or nanoflakes and nanoparticles. Bulk magnets were fabricated by hot pressing the precursor composite powders. Maximum energy product (BH)max was as high as 22 MGOe.

 Impact / Benefits:

 Our efforts will provide the fundamental innovations and breakthroughs, which could have a major impact in re-establishing the United States as a leader in the science, technology, and manufacturing of rare earth permanent magnets.

 The success in the development of the new nanocomposite magnets will directly result in the improvement of the functionality of electromagnetic devices and eventually lead to new applications not possible with the current permanent magnets. The most well-known applications include hybrid cars (permanent magnet motors, generators,  sensors  and actuators), spacecraft (momentum wheels, reaction wheels, stepper motors, ion propulsion), microwave sources (traveling wave tube amplifiers, klystrons, magnetrons), microwave components (isolators, circulators), inertial guidance systems (accelerometers, gyros), and other commercial systems (computer disk drives, printers, audio systems, satellite communication, medical imaging,  stepper motors, etc.).

Four undergraduate students were trained in the lab, under the REU program. The Lebanon/Lancaster Intermediate Unit IU 13 consisting of 30 high school teachers visited EEC on July 30th, 2010. This program continues to support local school districts in their efforts to bring current scientifically-based instruction to their classrooms by helping educators raise the bar through linking day-to-day instruction to real-life technologies in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM).  The teachers were trained for a day at EEC to enhance the knowledge and skills on how to use various materials, including engineered nanomaterials, for energy sustainability and alternative techno...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Fe-nanoparticle Coating of Anisotropic Magnet Powder for Nanocomposite Permanent Magnets with Enhanced (BH)max Project Outcome: Stronger permanent magnets are important for increasing the energy efficiency of communication systems, hybrid/electric vehicles, wind turbines, fossil fuel free transportation systems, and new energy storage systems. The new class of permanent magnets, called nanocomposite magnets, should dramatically increase the performance of permanent magnet systems used in static and dynamic applications. The challenges for the fabrication of nanocomposite magnets include (i) the development of nanostructure without contamination, (ii) densification without grain growth. In this project we propose to address these difficulties through a æbottom-upÆ approach to develop a technology for the fabrication of nanocomposite anisotropic precursors. We have synthesized, for the first time, samarium-cobalt permanent magnet nanoflakes with the magnetic performance similar to that of the bulk counterparts. We have also developed a method to uniformly deposit soft magnetic Fe and Fe-Co nanoparticles on the hard magnetic Sm-Co and Pr-Co core particles to form nanocomposite powder precursors. (Sm,Pr)Co5 and PrCo5 nanoflakes with different stoichiometries were synthesized as a hard magnetic precursor. The nanoflakes had a thickness in the range of 10-100 nm, which were fabricated by surfactant assisted high energy ball milling. Soft magnetic Fe and Fe-Co nanoparticles were chemically synthesized. The saturation magnetization, Ms, ranged from 18 kG to 20 kG for Fe nanoparticles and from 19 to 22 kG for Fe-Co nanoparticles. Anisotropic Sm-Co/Fe and Sm-Co/Fe-Co composite powders were formed by high energy blending from precursor micron-size powders or nanoflakes and nanoparticles. Bulk magnets were fabricated by hot pressing the precursor composite powders. Maximum energy product (BH)max was as high as 22 MGOe. Impact / Benefits: Our efforts will provide the fundamental innovations and breakthroughs, which could have a major impact in re-establishing the United States as a leader in the science, technology, and manufacturing of rare earth permanent magnets. The success in the development of the new nanocomposite magnets will directly result in the improvement of the functionality of electromagnetic devices and eventually lead to new applications not possible with the current permanent magnets. The most well-known applications include hybrid cars (permanent magnet motors, generators, sensors and actuators), spacecraft (momentum wheels, reaction wheels, stepper motors, ion propulsion), microwave sources (traveling wave tube amplifiers, klystrons, magnetrons), microwave components (isolators, circulators), inertial guidance systems (accelerometers, gyros), and other commercial systems (computer disk drives, printers, audio systems, satellite communication, medical imaging, stepper motors, etc.). Four undergraduate students were trained in the lab, under the REU program. The Lebanon/Lancaster Intermediate Unit IU 13 consisting of 30 high school teachers visited EEC on July 30th, 2010. This program continues to support local school districts in their efforts to bring current scientifically-based instruction to their classrooms by helping educators raise the bar through linking day-to-day instruction to real-life technologies in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). The teachers were trained for a day at EEC to enhance the knowledge and skills on how to use various materials, including engineered nanomaterials, for energy sustainability and alternative technologies for fossil fuels. The teachers were also introduced to the typical lab work including synthesis of new magnet materials, nanoparticles, consolidation of magnet powders and magnet testing. Patents: 1. A. Gabay, B. Z.
